summary: Raymond Rocca is mentioned in several documents related to investigations and inquiries into CIA activities, including the JFK assassination. He appears in the context of requests from the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) for information on individuals and entities of interest. Rocca's name is included in lists of individuals for whom the Central Cover Staff (CCS) held files. He is also mentioned in a transcript of a SSCIA hearing featuring testimony from DCI William Colby and in an inventory of Rockefeller Commission files. One document summarizes a meeting with the Warren Commission on March 12, 1964, discussing the CIA's involvement and information related to Lee Harvey Oswald and Jack Ruby. Another document mentions a meeting of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) in September 1963. The documents suggest Rocca was a figure of interest in investigations related to the CIA and the JFK assassination, likely due to his role within the agency.
significance: Raymond Rocca's significance in the JFK context stems from his association with the CIA and his appearance in documents related to investigations into the assassination. The documents suggest he was a person of interest to the HSCA and other investigative bodies looking into potential CIA involvement or knowledge related to the assassination.
